content.description: <math alttext="2 N O gas plus O 2 gas produces 2 N O 2 gas" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>NO</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>â†’</mo><mn>2</mn><msub><mrow><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>NO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>
content.question: Reactant Initial Concentration <math alttext="N O" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NO</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="0.0028 molar" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.0028</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.2em"></mspace><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="O 2 " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="0.0014 molar" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.0014</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.20em"></mspace><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> The oxidation of <math alttext="N O gas" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NO</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> producing <math alttext="N O 2 gas" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>NO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> is represented by the chemical equation shown above. The initial concentrations of <math alttext="N O" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NO</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="O 2 " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> are given in the table above. The changes in the concentration of <math alttext="N O gas" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NO</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> as a function of time are shown in the following graph. Under the same conditions, one of the following graphs represents the changes in the concentration of <math alttext="O 2 gas" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> over the same period of time. Which graph best represents the changes in concentration of <math alttext="O 2 gas" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>, and why?

choices.label: Graph 1, because the rate of <math alttext="O 2 " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> consumption is half the rate at which <math alttext="N O" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NO</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is consumed; two molecules of <math alttext="N O" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NO</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> react for each molecule of <math alttext="O 2 " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> that reacts.

Graph 1, because <math alttext="O 2 " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> molecules are consumed at a slower rate at the beginning of the reaction when there are not as many molecules of <math alttext="N O 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>NO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> produced.

Graph 2, because there is a large excess of <math alttext="O 2 " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> molecules and its concentration will not change drastically over time.

Graph 2, because a collision between three molecules to form a product has a low probability and the concentration of <math alttext="O 2 " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> will remain relatively constant.

content.answer: Graph 1, because the rate of <math alttext="O 2 " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> consumption is half the rate at which <math alttext="N O" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NO</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is consumed; two molecules of <math alttext="N O" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NO</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> react for each molecule of <math alttext="O 2 " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> that reacts.

skill.text: 6.E: Provide reasoning to justify a claim using connections between particulate and macroscopic scales or levels.
